Old Boy (manga) is a Japanese manga series written by Garon Tsuchiya and illustrated by Nobuaki Minegishi. The narrative follows the protagonist Shinichi Gotō, a man who, after a decade of incarceration in a private prison, is suddenly freed. After his release, Gotō must find his captors and discover the reason for his confinement. "Old Boy" was serialized in the Futabasha magazine "Weekly Manga Action" from 1996 to 1998, with a total of 79 chapters among eight collected volumes released during that time. The series was picked up for North American localization by Dark Horse Comics and released between 2006 and 2007.

Mangaka Shin Kibayashi serves as editor-in-chief of the app and pens several of the app's titles under his numerous pseudonyms. Garo (magazine) was a monthly manga anthology magazine in Japan, founded in 1964 by Katsuichi Nagai. It specialized in alternative and avant-garde manga. History. Katsuichi Nagai founded "Garo" in July 1964 with the help of Sanpei Shirato, naming it after one of Shirato's ninja characters. The first series published in "Garo" was Shirato's ninja drama "Kamui", which with its themes of class struggle and anti-authoritarian ism was a hit with college students. Garo attracted several influential "gekiga" artists such as Yoshihiro Tatsumi and Yoshiharu Tsuge, and discovered and promoted many new artists. "Garo" circulation at the peak of its popularity in 1971 was over eighty thousand.

Tuition is free, and students attend 20 lectures from professional writers, artists and editors throughout the year for a total of 100 hours. After leaving junior high school, Buronson entered the Japan Air Self-Defense Force because his family was poor. He graduated from there in 1967 and served as an Air Force radar mechanic. In 1970 he left the Self-Defense Force and was hired by Hiroshi Motomiya as a manga assistant in 1971.

Ryoichi Ikegami is one of the most acclaimed Japanese manga artists, renowned for his realistic art style and collaborations with prominent writers. Over his decades-long career, Ikegami has illustrated numerous major manga series, often working in partnership with notable authors such as Kazuo Koike, Sho Fumimura, and Buronson. His works frequently span genres including crime, action, historical drama, and psychological thriller, reflecting his versatility and ability to adapt to different narrative styles.

Below is a comprehensive overview of manga series drawn by Ryoichi Ikegami, including their collaborators, general publication timeframe, and thematic focus.

## Major Manga Series Drawn by Ryoichi Ikegami

| Manga Series         | Collaborating Writer   | Publication Period      | Genre / Themes                    |
|---------------------|-----------------------|------------------------|------------------------------------|
| Mai, the Psychic Girl    | Kazuya Kudo           | Early 1980s            | Psychological thriller, action     |
| Crying Freeman           | Kazuo Koike           | 1986-1988              | Crime, assassination, thriller     |
| Sanctuary                | Sho Fumimura          | 1990-1995              | Drama, coming-of-age, social issues|
| Odyssey                  | Sho Fumimura          | Mid-1990s (approx.)    | Modern drama, existential themes   |
| Strain                   | Buronson              | 1996-1998              | Crime, assassin protagonist        |
| Heat                     | Buronson              | 1999-2004              | Gangster/crime, urban drama        |
| Lord (Chō-Sangokushi)    | Buronson              | 2004-2011              | Historical, Three Kingdoms epic    |
| Soul Lord 2              | Buronson              | 2011-2013 (sequel)     | Historical, epic follow-up         |
| BOX (暗い箱)              | Garon Tsuchiya        | Late 1990s-Early 2000s | Contemporary psychological drama   |
| Spider-Man (Manga version)| Unspecified           | 1970s-1980s            | Superhero adaptation               |
| Begin                    | Buronson              | 2016-present           | Urban contemporary drama           |

### Detailed Overview of Each Series

#### 1. **Mai, the Psychic Girl**
Written by Kazuya Kudo, this series follows Mai Kuju, a girl endowed with powerful psychic abilities and targeted by organizations seeking to exploit her powers. It is recognized for its mature portrayal of psychological and psychic phenomena, and was one of the earliest manga to introduce complex female protagonists in Western publishing.

#### 2. **Crying Freeman**
Co-created with writer Kazuo Koike, this influential series depicts the story of Yo Hinomura ("Crying Freeman"), an assassin trained by a Chinese crime organization. Known for its stylish artwork, gritty realism, and emotional depth, Crying Freeman became an international cult classic and inspired adaptations into films and anime OVAs.

#### 3. **Sanctuary**
Collaborating with Sho Fumimura, Ikegami’s Sanctuary is a critically acclaimed drama focusing on two childhood friends navigating Japan’s underworld and society during periods of economic upheaval. It is noted for its sophisticated plot structure, mature character development, and depiction of 1980s Japanese society.

#### 4. **Odyssey**
This series, also written by Sho Fumimura, explores themes of existential crisis and the search for meaning in modern life. Though less globally recognized than some of Ikegami’s other works, it further demonstrates his capacity to handle introspective, modern drama in manga form.

#### 5. **Strain**
Created with writer Buronson, Strain follows professional assassin Mayo, who faces moral dilemmas after being coerced into killing. The story is notable for its dark tone and psychological complexity, exploring the human cost of violence and survival.

#### 6. **Heat**
Another collaboration with Buronson, Heat is set in Shinjuku and revolves around Tatsumi Karasawa, who rises through Tokyo’s criminal underworld. This series won the Shogakukan Manga Award and stands out for its vivid depiction of urban decay, power struggles, and psychological tension among yakuza and gangsters.

#### 7. **Lord (Chō-Sangokushi)**
Based on China’s Three Kingdoms period, Lord is a historical epic illustrated by Ikegami and written by Buronson. It blends traditional storytelling with modern narrative techniques and is celebrated for its dynamic action sequences and characterizations.

#### 8. **Soul Lord 2**
A sequel to Lord, this series continues the epic tale of ancient warfare and political intrigue, extending the creative partnership between Ikegami and Buronson into new territory.

#### 9. **BOX (暗い箱)**
Ikegami worked with Garon Tsuchiya on BOX, a psychological manga whose exact plot details are not widely documented. The series contributes to Ikegami’s portfolio of mature, dramatic works dealing with complex human emotions and relationships.

#### 10. **Spider-Man (Manga version)**
Ikegami illustrated a manga adaptation of the Marvel superhero Spider-Man. While not extensively documented in available sources, this project shows Ikegami’s range, taking on mainstream superhero material and adapting it for a Japanese audience.

#### 11. **Begin**
Currently serialized, this work is another collaboration with Buronson. It continues Ikegami’s exploration of contemporary urban drama, often featuring morally ambiguous characters and intricate narratives.

## Collaborative Partnerships

A defining feature of Ryoichi Ikegami’s career has been his recurring collaborations with leading Japanese manga writers. These partnerships have yielded some of the most memorable stories in Japanese popular culture. Notably:

- **Kazuo Koike**: Together on “Crying Freeman”.
- **Sho Fumimura**: Co-created both “Sanctuary” and “Odyssey”.
- **Buronson**: Multiple collaborations, including “Strain”, “Heat”, “Lord”, “Soul Lord 2”, and “Begin”.
- **Garon Tsuchiya**: Joint work on “BOX”.
- **Kazuya Kudo**: “Mai, the Psychic Girl”.

## Artistic Style and Influence

Ikegami’s detailed, realistic illustrations distinguish his work from more stylized manga artists. His depictions of action, emotion, and character are praised for their depth and authenticity. Many of his works pushed boundaries—particularly regarding mature content and complex, adult-oriented themes—which broadened the appeal and sophistication of manga as a medium.

## Conclusion

In summary, Ryoichi Ikegami has drawn a wide array of manga series, spanning genres and collaborating with some of Japan’s foremost writers. His portfolio includes landmark titles in crime, historical epic, psychological thriller, and even superhero adaptation, underscoring his versatility and impact on the manga industry. Below is a markdown table summarizing his main works:

| Manga Title             | Writer(s)               | Primary Genre/Theme                  |
|------------------------|-------------------------|--------------------------------------|
| Mai, the Psychic Girl  | Kazuya Kudo             | Psychological thriller               |
| Crying Freeman         | Kazuo Koike             | Crime, thriller, psychological drama |
| Sanctuary              | Sho Fumimura            | Drama, urban realism                 |
| Odyssey                | Sho Fumimura            | Modern drama, existential themes     |
| Strain                 | Buronson                | Assassin, crime                      |
| Heat                   | Buronson                | Gangster, crime                      |
| Lord (Chō-Sangokushi)  | Buronson                | Historical, epic                     |
| Soul Lord 2            | Buronson                | Historical, sequel                   |
| BOX (暗い箱)            | Garon Tsuchiya          | Psychological drama                  |
| Spider-Man (Manga ver.)| Unspecified             | Superhero                            |
| Begin                  | Buronson                | Contemporary urban drama             |

Collectively, these works illustrate Ikegami’s significant contribution to manga’s evolution, particularly in blending realistic narrative storytelling with compelling artistic execution. His influence persists among new generations of manga artists and readers worldwide.

Harmony Korine is a highly distinctive American filmmaker known for his unconventional narratives and offbeat style. Among his body of work, he has served as both screenwriter and director in several films. The most notable example—and widely recognized as his directorial debut—is the 1997 film "Gummo."

## Harmony Korine’s Role as Screenwriter and Director

In the realm of independent cinema, it’s not uncommon for filmmakers to take on multiple roles, especially when working on projects with limited budgets or unique visions. Harmony Korine exemplifies this trend, often writing and directing his own films to ensure his creative intentions are fully realized. However, his earliest major project where he exercised both these roles was "Gummo."

### Gummo (1997)

"Gummo" stands out in Korine’s career as the film where he first combined his talents as a screenwriter and director. This experimental drama tells the story of life in Xenia, Ohio—a town affected by the aftermath of a tornado—with a series of interconnected vignettes rather than a traditional narrative structure. The film features vignettes exploring the lives of disaffected youth and marginalized characters, capturing the raw, unvarnished reality of small-town America.

Korine’s dual role on "Gummo" allowed him significant creative control over the storytelling process. He shaped every aspect of the film, from the dialogue and character development to the visual style and editing rhythms. As both writer and director, Korine was able to infuse the movie with his unique voice and vision, resulting in a work that is both challenging and thought-provoking.

The production of "Gummo" marked a turning point for Korine, launching him into the spotlight as an innovative force in contemporary cinema. The film received mixed reviews upon its release, praised for its boldness but critiqued for its fragmented structure. Over time, however, it has gained recognition as a cult classic and a defining piece of late-1990s independent filmmaking.

### Other Films Where Harmony Korine Served as Screenwriter and Director

While "Gummo" was his debut as both writer and director, Korine continued this practice in subsequent projects. Here are some additional films where he played both roles:

| Film Title            | Year | Additional Details                                |
|-----------------------|------|---------------------------------------------------|
| Gummo                 | 1997 | Directed and wrote; his debut feature             |
| Julien Donkey-Boy     | 1999 | Wrote and directed; Dogme 95-inspired approach    |
| Mister Lonely         | 2007 | Co-wrote with brother Avi Korine; directed        |
| Spring Breakers       | 2012 | Wrote and directed; Hollywood studio release      |

It's important to note that in "Mister Lonely," Korine co-wrote the screenplay with his brother, Avi Korine, so while he retained direction duties, he was not solely the screenwriter for that project. Similarly, for "Spring Breakers," he was credited as both writer and director.

## Contextualizing the Question

The question—“Harmony Korine was both screenwriter and director of what movie?”—commonly arises in discussions about his early career or in trivia settings. It seeks to distinguish between the works he contributed to as solely a screenwriter (such as "Kids," directed by Larry Clark) and those where he assumed full authorship through both writing and directing.

While Korine has taken on both roles in several films, "Gummo" is the most significant and commonly referenced title associated with this dual capacity. This is especially true in educational contexts, film retrospectives, and quiz scenarios, where “Gummo” serves as the definitive answer.

## Why "Gummo" Is the Primary Answer

The association of "Gummo" with both writing and directing by Harmony Korine is reinforced by the following factors:

- **Directorial Debut:** "Gummo" was Korine’s first feature-length film, marking his transition from screenwriting to directing.
- **Critical Acclaim and Legacy:** Over the years, "Gummo" has become a reference point in film studies for its radical approach to storytelling and its depiction of American subculture.
- **Frequent Reference:** In biographical summaries, interviews, and film synopses, "Gummo" is consistently highlighted as the project where Korine fulfilled both major creative roles.

## Conclusion

To directly answer the question: Harmony Korine was both screenwriter and director of the film "Gummo" (1997), which remains one of his most influential and iconic works. While he later repeated this combination of roles in movies like "Julien Donkey-Boy," "Mister Lonely," and "Spring Breakers," "Gummo" is the most prominent and historically significant example. His ability to write and direct his own material showcases his singular artistic vision and cemented his reputation as a daring and uncompromising filmmaker in the landscape of contemporary cinema.

The Agnivanshi lineage (Agnivansha or Agnikula) is one of the three lineages into which the Rajput clans, Parihar s (Gurjara pratihara) divided, the others being the Suryavanshi (descended from Surya, the sun god) and the Chandravanshi (descended from Chandra, the moon god). According to medieval legends, there are four Agnivanshi clans: Chauhan s (Chahamanas), Parihar s (Pratiharas), Parmar s (Paramaras) and Solankis (Chaulukyas). Apart from Rajputs, several other Indian communities and dynasties have legends of fire-born ancestry.

Balachandran’s career and the films he contributed to as a screenwriter. P. Balachandran, full name Padmanabhan Balachandran Nair, was a prominent Indian writer, playwright, and scenarist who made significant contributions to Malayalam cinema and literature. His work is highly regarded, particularly in the realms of drama and film storytelling in Kerala.

## P. Balachandran’s Notable Filmography

P. Balachandran wrote screenplays for several influential Malayalam films throughout his career. Among these, some of the most significant include:

| Film Title            | Year  | Director           |
|-----------------------|-------|--------------------|
| Ulladakkam            | 1991  | Kamal              |
| Pavithram             | 1994  | T. K. Rajeev Kumar |
| Agnidevan             | 1995  | —                  |
| Punaradhivasam        | 2000  | V. K. Prakash      |
| Kammatti Paadam       | 2016  | Rajeev Ravi        |

This table summarizes the key films where P. Balachandran worked as a screenwriter and their respective directors.

### Films and Their Directors

#### 1. **Ulladakkam (1991)**
Directed by Kamal, *Ulladakkam* is a psychological thriller renowned for its exploration of psychoanalytic themes and transference. The screenplay, written by P. Balachandran, explores complex human relationships and mental states, earning critical acclaim and several awards. Kamal is celebrated as one of the leading directors of Malayalam cinema, and his collaboration with Balachandran produced a landmark film.

#### 2. **Pavithram (1994)**
The film *Pavithram*, directed by T. K. Rajeev Kumar, is a drama that delves into the emotional complexities between siblings separated by age and circumstances. Written by P. Balachandran, the film stands out for its sensitive script and compelling performances, especially by Mohanlal and Shobana. T. K. Rajeev Kumar’s direction ensured that the nuanced emotions central to Balachandran's writing were fully realized on screen.

#### 3. **Agnidevan (1995)**
*Agnidevan*, another screenplay penned by P. Balachandran, poses a challenge to locate specific directorial information. Despite references to the film in profiles and retrospectives of Balachandran’s work, publicly available databases do not readily yield details about its director. This could imply it was an independent, lesser-known production or possibly a short film.

#### 4. **Punaradhivasam (2000)**
*Punaradhivasam* was directed by V. K. Prakash. This drama was both critically and award-winning, notably receiving the National Film Award for Best Feature Film in Malayalam. The screenplay by P. Balachandran addresses family dynamics and reconciliation, and V. K. Prakash’s direction brought these elements to life with sensitivity and depth.

#### 5. **Kammatti Paadam (2016)**
*Kammatti Paadam*, a contemporary action drama set in a Kochi slum, was directed by Rajeev Ravi. The screenplay, authored by P. Balachandran, received praise for its social commentary and portrayal of marginalized communities. Rajeev Ravi’s atmospheric direction and cinematic style elevated the film’s narrative impact, making it a modern classic of New Wave Malayalam cinema.

## The Role of Screenwriters in Malayalam Cinema

P. Balachandran’s contribution as a screenwriter highlights the importance of literary talent in shaping narratives for Indian cinema. In Malayalam cinema, writers often collaborate closely with directors to craft emotionally rich, socially relevant, and culturally resonant stories. Directors such as Kamal, T. K. Rajeev Kumar, V. K. Prakash, and Rajeev Ravi are recognized for their ability to interpret scripts with subtlety and artistry, elevating the overall quality of the cinematic output.

Each of these collaborations resulted in films that not only entertained but also stimulated reflection on societal issues, family relations, personal growth, and cultural identities. The success of these films owes much to the synergy between P. Balachandran’s writing and the vision of their directors.

## Noteworthy Achievements

Some films crafted through this partnership won prestigious awards, and others became cult classics within regional cinema. For example:

- *Ulladakkam* earned critical acclaim, special recognition from critics, and various state-level awards for its psychological realism and technical excellence.
- *Punaradhivasam* achieved national recognition with the National Film Award, cementing both P. Balachandran and V. K. Prakash as significant figures in Malayalam filmmaking.
- *Kammatti Paadam* received widespread appreciation for its socio-political relevance and direction.

## Conclusion

In summary, several acclaimed directors have helmed films where P. Balachandran served as screenwriter. These include:
- **Kamal**, for *Ulladakkam* (1991)
- **T. K. Rajeev Kumar**, for *Pavithram* (1994)
- **V. K. Prakash**, for *Punaradhivasam* (2000)
- **Rajeev Ravi**, for *Kammatti Paadam* (2016)

While information about the director of *Agnidevan* (1995) remains elusive, it is clear that P. Balachandran’s screenplays have been interpreted by some of Malayalam cinema’s finest directors, resulting in enduring cultural and artistic legacies.

His work exemplifies the power of storytelling in film and the essential role of collaboration between writers and directors in creating meaningful cinema.

However, the five funnels also had a symbolic importance, as it was popularly considered that the number of funnels was indicative of performance, and some navies were known to add extra fake funnels to impress dignitaries in less advanced countries. She was turned over to the Sevastopol port authorities before being stricken on 14 August 1907. She was re-designated as "Stricken Vessel Nr. 3" on 22 April 1912 before being sunk as a torpedo target for the Black Sea Fleet. Design and description. "Ekaterina II" was long at the waterline and long overall.

The Russian Empire had a diverse and extensive naval and merchant marine presence throughout its history, spanning from its foundation in the late 17th century until the revolution of 1917. Ships registered under the Russian Empire can be broadly categorized into two main groups: warships (official naval vessels) and merchant vessels (commercial ships), each with numerous subclasses and technological evolutions over time.

---

## 1. Overview of Ship Registration in the Russian Empire

Ships registered to the Russian Empire—whether for military or commercial purposes—were defined by their country of origin, flag, and official affiliation with imperial institutions. Warships were directly controlled by the Imperial Russian Navy, which was managed by various state bodies including the Vladimirsky Prikaz and Admiralteyskiy Prikaz. Merchant ships, on the other hand, were owned and operated by private or state-associated companies, but bore the imperial flag and sometimes could be requisitioned by the navy in wartime. This system enabled Russia to maintain a large and varied maritime presence globally, especially as it expanded along the Baltic, Black, and Pacific Seas.

---

## 2. Imperial Russian Navy: Warship Classes

### 2.1 Early Naval Force Structure

At the founding of the Imperial Russian Navy in 1696, the empire began assembling a force modeled largely on Western European lines. By 1745, the navy comprised 130 vessels, including:
- **36 ships of the line**
- **9 frigates**
- **3 shnyavas** (light two-mast ships used for reconnaissance)
- **5 bombardier ships**
- **77 auxiliary vessels**

This structure grew rapidly during the reigns of Peter the Great and Catherine the Great, making Russia one of the world’s leading maritime powers by the early 19th century.

### 2.2 Major Warship Types

Over the centuries, Russian warships evolved technologically. Below is a description of key classes and representative ships, grouped chronologically and by type:

#### Ships of the Line
These wooden-hulled, heavily armed ships formed the backbone of Russia’s sea power from the late 17th through mid-19th century. Notable classes and ships included:
- **Tsar Konstantin**-class (4 units)
- **Selafail**-class (23 units)
- **Trekh Sviatitelei**-class (7 units)
- **Borodino**-class (2 units)
- **Imperator Nikolai I** (1860, 1st-rate wooden steam-powered ship)
- Other significant classes: “Mikhail Arkhangel”, “Sviataya Ekaterina”, “Uriil”, “Nord-Adler”, “Sankt-Mikhail”, “Slava Rossii”, “Sviatoi Pavel”, “Azia”.

#### Frigates and Corvettes
Frigates and corvettes were versatile warships of varying sizes, often serving in squadrons and overseas deployments. Examples include:
- **Pervyi**-class (2 units)
- **Apostol Andrei**-class (2 units)
- **Piotr Apostol**-class (6 units)
- **Tenedos**-class (6 units)
- **Steam frigates**: “Razboinik”-class, “Almaz”-class, “Kreiser”-class

#### Gunboats and Smaller Vessels
Small paddle frigates, rowing frigates, and steamboats were deployed for riverine, coastal, and auxiliary roles, including transport, reconnaissance, and support.

#### Ironclads and Modern Battleships
As technology advanced, Russia commissioned armored and steam-powered warships:
- **Ekaterina II** (ironclad, lead ship of her class, launched 1880s)
- **Imperator Aleksandr II** (battleship, completed 1880s–90s)
- **Imperator Pavel I** and sister ships (pre-dreadnought battleships, built ~1900s)
- **Imperatritsa Mariya** class (dreadnoughts, completed around WWI)

#### Cruisers and Destroyers
Late 19th and early 20th-century expansions yielded protected and armored cruisers, as well as torpedo boats and destroyers:
- **Protected cruisers**: “Svetlana” (1896), “Askold”, “Bogatyr”, “Pallada” (multiple variants)
- **Destroyers and torpedo boats**: “Leitenant Burakov” class (11), “Tverdyi” class, “Kapitan Yurasovskiy” class, “Deyatelnyi” class, “Finn” class

#### Submarines and Icebreakers
Russia fielded the world’s first operational submarine squadron and pioneered new ship types for Arctic exploration:
- **Early submarines**: 7 boats created before 1905, including “Som”, “Delfin”, “Keta”
- **First polar icebreaker**: **Yermak** (launched 1898), developed under Vice-Admiral Makarov

---

## 3. Merchant Marine and Commercial Shipping

### 3.1 Major Shipping Companies

Unlike traditional state navies, Russia’s merchant marine was dominated by joint-stock and privately owned companies, notably:
- **Russian Steam Navigation and Trading Company (ROPiT)**: Established 1856, by 1901 it operated 72 steamships with routes connecting Russia and Mediterranean/Black Sea ports.
- **Voluntary Fleet (Dobroflot)**: Founded in 1878, focused on Far Eastern trade and troop transport, soon playing a strategic role in both Russo-Japanese War and WWI.
- **Russian-American Company**: Operated Atlantic and Pacific trade, including famous exploration vessels such as “Neva” and “Nadezhda”.

### 3.2 Scale and Wartime Role

By 1901, ROPiT alone had grown to one of the largest steamship fleets in Europe. During WWI, approximately **200 merchant ships** were mobilized for military purposes, primarily in the Black Sea. This rapid conversion underscored the flexibility and importance of merchant vessels under the Russian Empire.

---

## 4. Timeline Table: Key Numbers

| Period           | Warships Present                       | Merchant Ships Available              |
|------------------|---------------------------------------|---------------------------------------|
| 1745             | 130 vessels (including 36 ships of line) | –                                     |
| 1853 (Crimean War) | 40 battleships, 15 frigates, 24 corvettes, 24 brigs, 16 steam frigates, plus auxiliaries | –                                     |
| Early 1900s      | Dozens of modern ironclads, dreadnoughts, cruisers, destroyers, submarines, icebreakers | ROPiT: 72 steamships (1901), Dobroflot: several dozen |
| 1914 (WWI Start) | Multiple classes across Baltic, Black Sea, and Pacific Fleets | ~200 merchant ships mobilized         |

---

## 5. Representative Ships and Their Roles

Below are some iconic examples and their significance:

- **“Shtandart”**: First flagship of Peter the Great, symbol of imperial naval foundation.
- **“Aurora”**: A protected cruiser, famously fired the signal shot at the start of the October Revolution.
- **“Imperator Nikolai I”**: One of the last great wooden ships of the line, later used for training.
- **“Yermak”**: World’s first purpose-built polar icebreaker, vital for Arctic navigation and exploration.
- **Merchant liners**: “SS Russian” (British cargo ship, but sometimes mistaken for Russian), and ROPiT’s fleet of ocean-going steamers for global trade.

---

## 6. Summary

The Russian Empire’s fleet encompassed hundreds of warships across a wide array of classes—from wooden sailing ships of the line to modern steel battleships, cruisers, destroyers, and submarines. These vessels played central roles in the expansion of imperial power, in maintaining maritime security, and in sustaining vast colonial and trade networks.

On the civilian side, commercial ships maintained lucrative transcontinental routes and could be quickly converted to naval auxiliary or transport roles during times of conflict. The combination of organized naval power and an active merchant marine allowed Russia to establish itself as a dominant regional and global maritime actor through much of its imperial history.

In sum, ships registered to the Russian Empire ranged from massive sailing warships and ironclads to fast merchant steamers and polar explorers, reflecting both the technological progress and strategic ambitions of the empire up until its dissolution in 1917.

In the history of the Women’s National Basketball Association (WNBA), the Seattle Storm have made several high-profile selections in the WNBA Draft, but the most notable and frequently referenced player is **Jewell Loyd**.

Jewell Loyd was selected first overall by the Seattle Storm in the 2015 WNBA Draft. Her selection took place on April 16, 2015, during the draft held at Mohegan Sun Arena. Loyd had a standout collegiate career at Notre Dame, where she emerged as one of the premier guards in women’s college basketball. Her aggressive playmaking, scoring ability, and leadership qualities made her an immediate impact player for the Storm. 

During her rookie season, Loyd showed flashes of greatness. She quickly became a key contributor to the team’s roster and continued to develop into a dynamic and versatile guard over the next few seasons. She played a crucial role in the Storm’s championship run in 2018, helping the franchise secure their third WNBA title. Loyd has since become one of the faces of the franchise, known for her scoring prowess, defensive skills, and clutch performances in important games.

Aside from Jewell Loyd, the Seattle Storm also selected Kaleena Mosqueda-Lewis with the third overall pick in the same draft. Mosqueda-Lewis brought experience from her successful tenure at the University of Connecticut and added depth and versatility to the Storm’s lineup. While Mosqueda-Lewis made significant contributions, particularly in scoring and rebounding, Jewell Loyd remains the focal point associated with the Storm’s draft selection due to her greater overall impact and longer tenure with the team.

To summarize:

- **Jewell Loyd** was the player selected first overall by the Seattle Storm in the 2015 WNBA Draft.
- She joined the Storm after an outstanding collegiate career at Notre Dame.
- Throughout her career, Loyd has been instrumental to the Storm’s successes, including their championship in 2018.
- Other players such as Kaleena Mosqueda-Lewis were also selected by the Storm in the same draft, but Jewell Loyd stands out as the most prominent selection.

This selection was significant not just for the Storm’s future success but also for elevating the standard of play in the league, thanks to Loyd’s talent and determination on the court. Her journey from the draft to becoming a cornerstone player for the Storm exemplifies how the WNBA Draft can transform teams through strategic selections.

When considering the question “Where was a Bishop of Bradford taught?”, it’s important to recognize that the title “Bishop of Bradford” refers to several different individuals throughout history, particularly in the context of the Church of England. The Diocese of Bradford was established in the early 20th century and has had various incumbents over the years. Each bishop brought unique backgrounds and educational paths to their service, reflecting the evolution of both the church and broader educational opportunities during their lifetimes. Below is a detailed synthesis of the educational backgrounds of notable Bishops of Bradford, which covers several periods of the diocese's existence, along with their principal places of study or higher learning. --- ## Educational Backgrounds of Bishops of Bradford ### 1. Arthur William Thomson Perowne (First Bishop of Bradford, 1919–1931) Arthur William Thomson Perowne was the inaugural Bishop of Bradford. He hailed from an accomplished ecclesiastical family and received his education at two notable institutions: - **Haileybury and Imperial Service College**: Perowne attended this prestigious secondary school, which historically prepared many for careers in public service and the clergy. - **King's College, Cambridge**: At Cambridge, Perowne earned a Bachelor of Arts (BA), subsequently promoted to Master of Arts (MA), and ultimately achieved a Doctor of Divinity (DD). His studies at King's College provided him with a classical academic foundation essential for high-level church administration and leadership. Perowne’s robust education in classics and divinity underpinned his influential tenure as Bishop of Bradford. --- ### 2. Nick Baines (Last Diocesan Bishop of Bradford, 2011–2014) Nick Baines served as the final diocesan Bishop of Bradford before the diocese was merged into the new Diocese of Leeds. His academic journey is marked by both general and specialized study: - **Holt Comprehensive School, Liverpool**: Baines received his secondary education here. - **University of Bradford**: He completed a Bachelor of Arts (BA) degree with honors in German and French. This indicates proficiency in languages, potentially supporting his role in ecumenical relations and communication. - **Trinity College, Bristol**: After working as a linguist, Baines pursued theological studies at Trinity College Bristol, earning another BA in theological studies. This further education was pivotal in his path to ordination and high church office. His diverse educational experiences gave him the skills required for multifaceted leadership within the church. --- ### 3. Toby Howarth (First Area Bishop of Bradford, 2014–present) Toby Howarth became the first Area Bishop of Bradford following the restructuring of the dioceses in the Church of England. Notably, his educational background is unusual and noteworthy among contemporary bishops: - **Yale University (USA)**: Howarth was educated at Yale, one of America’s Ivy League universities. This distinguished him from his peers, as most Church of England bishops typically studied in the UK. - **Wycliffe Hall, Oxford**: Here, Howarth undertook his Anglican theological training. Wycliffe Hall is known for its evangelical orientation and rigorous preparation for ministry. - **University of Birmingham**: He went on to complete an MA at Birmingham University, likely focusing on some aspect of religious studies or theology. Howarth’s international academic experience, especially at Yale, set him apart and broadened his global perspective in church leadership. --- ### 4. Tom Butler (Acting/ Mentor Bishop, involved in the transition) Tom Butler, although not a diocesan bishop of Bradford himself, played a significant interim role and was actively involved in the transition period after the dissolution of the diocese. His educational credentials reflect a modern scientific approach combined with theological training: - **King Edward VI Five Ways School, Birmingham**: Butler’s secondary education took place at this independent school in Birmingham. - **University of Leeds**: He obtained a First-Class Honours Bachelor of Science (BSc), followed by a Master of Science (MSc), and a PhD in electronics. This combination of advanced scientific studies and theological formation is rare in episcopal appointments. After his academic career, Butler trained for ordination at the College of the Resurrection in Yorkshire, completing the theological preparation required for his ministry. --- ## Summary Table: Key Educational Institutions of Bishops of Bradford | Bishop | Primary Institution(s) of Higher Education | Secondary School | Additional Notes | |------------------------|--------------------------------------------------|-----------------------------------|---------------------------------------| | Arthur William Perowne | King's College, Cambridge | Haileybury and Imperial Service | Degree: BA, MA, DD | | Nick Baines | Trinity College, Bristol

Early in the 20th century, like Perowne, bishops were often drawn from Cambridge or Oxford circles, trained for administrative or scholarly leadership roles within the church and society. In subsequent decades, the doors opened to graduates from comprehensive schools like Holt, reflecting increasing inclusivity. Scott Z. Burns is an accomplished American screenwriter, director, and producer known for his insightful and often thought-provoking work in contemporary cinema. Over the course of his career, Burns has been responsible for writing several notable feature films, primarily working within the thriller, drama, and political genres. His screenwriting style frequently incorporates real-world events, societal issues, and psychological depth, resulting in critically acclaimed works that resonate with audiences and critics alike.

Below is a detailed overview of the major movies Scott Z. Burns has written screenplays for, including information about his collaborations and contributions to each film.

## Feature Films Screenwritten by Scott Z. Burns

### 1. The Bourne Ultimatum (2007)
**Year Released:** 2007  
**Role:** Co-writer  
**Collaborators:** Tony Gilroy, George Nolfi  

"The Bourne Ultimatum" is the third installment in the celebrated Jason Bourne film series, starring Matt Damon as the titular spy. Scott Z. Burns worked alongside Tony Gilroy and George Nolfi to craft the screenplay, which was based on elements taken from Robert Ludlum’s original novels and characters. Burns's contribution helped shape the film's intense pacing, intricate plotlines, and the psychological complexity of its protagonist. This film played a significant role in revitalizing the action-thriller genre during the late 2000s.

### 2. The Informant! (2009)
**Year Released:** 2009  
**Role:** Writer  
**Director:** Steven Soderbergh  
**Starring:** Matt Damon  

In "The Informant!", Scott Z. Burns adapted Kurt Eichenwald’s nonfiction book into a film that combines crime, comedy, and drama. The story centers on Mark Whitacre, a real-life whistleblower caught in a lysine price-fixing conspiracy. With a sharp script and clever tone, Burns explored themes of betrayal, ambition, and mental instability, showcasing his ability to translate complex factual material into engaging narrative form. The film exemplifies Burns's skill at blending real-world ethical dilemmas with cinematic storytelling.

### 3. Contagion (2011)
**Year Released:** 2011  
**Role:** Writer  
**Director:** Steven Soderbergh  
**Starring:** Marion Cotillard, Matt Damon, Kate Winslet, Laurence Fishburne, Jude Law, Bryan Cranston, and others  

"Contagion" stands as one of Burns’s most impactful screenplays, especially due to its prescient depiction of a global pandemic. Drawing inspiration from real epidemics such as SARS and the 2009 flu pandemic, Burns conducted extensive research and consulted with medical experts and representatives of health organizations worldwide. The screenplay interweaves multiple character-driven stories as the world grapples with the rapid spread of a deadly virus, addressing issues such as science, government response, public panic, and hope. The film gained renewed relevance during subsequent global health crises, highlighting the power and foresight of Burns’s writing.

### 4. Side Effects (2013)
**Year Released:** 2013  
**Role:** Writer  
**Director:** Steven Soderbergh  
**Starring:** Rooney Mara, Channing Tatum, Jude Law, Catherine Zeta-Jones  

Building on his successful partnership with Steven Soderbergh, Scott Z. Burns wrote the screenplay for "Side Effects," a psychological thriller examining the dangers and ethics of psychiatric medication. The story follows a woman who, after her husband returns from prison, seeks help for anxiety and depression before unraveling a dark conspiracy involving experimental drugs. Burns’s script blends suspenseful narrative twists with social commentary, focusing on trust, trauma, and the fragility of mental health in modern society.

### 5. The Report (2019)
**Year Released:** 2019  
**Role:** Writer and Director  
**Starring:** Adam Driver, Annette Bening, Jon Hamm  

"The Report" marked Scott Z. Burns’s evolution into directing as well as writing. The film dramatizes the true story of Senate staffer Daniel J. Jones, who leads an investigation into the CIA’s post-9/11 torture program. Burns spent years researching the subject matter, consulting with officials, journalists, and psychologists involved with the original inquiry. His dual roles as writer and director allowed him to infuse the project with authenticity and moral urgency, offering a critical reflection on governmental accountability and the consequences of institutional secrecy.

## Additional Insights

Scott Z. Burns’s approach to screenwriting involves a commitment to realism, often anchoring fictional stories in documented facts, events, and social phenomena. His experiences working in advertising and television commercials contributed to his mastery of narrative structure and timing—skills evident throughout his filmography.

Burns has also collaborated frequently with director Steven Soderbergh, resulting in a distinctive series of films characterized by tight plotting, ensemble casts, and topical relevance. While Burns’s early career included producing notable documentaries such as “An Inconvenient Truth,” his primary reputation stems from his work as a screenwriter and filmmaker.

Outside of these features, there is no publicly available record of Burns receiving credit as a screenwriter for any other major motion pictures. Although he may have engaged in earlier, uncredited drafts or brief creative input, the five films listed above represent the core of his recognized screenwriting achievements in the feature film arena.

## Conclusion

Scott Z. Burns is best known for his contributions as a screenwriter on several important films, particularly those exploring real-world issues through the lens of thriller and drama genres. His work includes “The Bourne Ultimatum,” “The Informant!” (both featuring Matt Damon), “Contagion,” “Side Effects,” and his solo-written/directed film “The Report.” Collectively, these films demonstrate his talent for crafting complex narratives grounded in current events, psychology, and social critique, making him a significant figure in contemporary screenwriting.

Provide citation.

David G. Hartwell was one of the most influential science fiction editors and anthologists in American publishing during the late twentieth and early twenty-first centuries. His editorial career spanned more than four decades and included thousands of novels and numerous acclaimed anthologies. One of his most celebrated pieces of literature as an editor is the anthology titled **"The Dark Descent,"** for which he received the prestigious World Fantasy Award for Best Anthology in 1988.

## Overview of David G. Hartwell’s Editorial Career

Hartwell began working in publishing in the early 1970s, eventually serving at major publishers such as Signet, Berkley Putnam, Pocket Books, and later Tor Books. He is recognized for bringing attention to innovative voices in science fiction and fantasy, championing new works, and shaping the landscape of speculative fiction literature. Hartwell was instrumental in founding several prominent imprints and book series, but his lasting legacy lies largely in his anthology work, critical essays, and awards-winning anthologies.

## "The Dark Descent": A Notable Edited Anthology

Among the many anthologies Hartwell edited, "**The Dark Descent**" stands out as a significant achievement in the field of speculative fiction. Published in the late 1980s, this anthology showcases a curated selection of dark fantasy and horror stories, carefully selected to highlight the genre’s most compelling and innovative writers of the time.

"The Dark Descent" was awarded the **World Fantasy Award for Best Anthology** in 1988. This honor reflects both the quality and influence of the stories included in the volume, as well as Hartwell's ability as an editor to identify and assemble outstanding contributions within the genre. Through such anthologies, Hartwell has played a pivotal role in highlighting emerging talent and preserving the diversity and richness of speculative fiction literature.

### Table: Key Facts About "The Dark Descent"

| Aspect                | Detail                                   |
|-----------------------|------------------------------------------|
| Editor                | David G. Hartwell                        |
| Type                  | Anthology                                |
| Genre                 | Dark fantasy, horror                     |
| Year Published        | Late 1980s (specific year varies by source) |
| Awards                | World Fantasy Award for Best Anthology (1988) |

## Other Significant Works Edited by Hartwell

While "The Dark Descent" is a major work, Hartwell’s editorial achievements extend beyond a single anthology:

- **"Year’s Best SF" Series**: Hartwell launched this annual anthology series in 1996, selecting the most exceptional short science fiction stories published each year. Later co-edited with Kathryn Cramer, this series became essential reading for fans and critics alike.
- **"Year’s Best Fantasy" Series**: Similarly, Hartwell, often alongside Kathryn Cramer, produced an annual anthology focused on outstanding fantasy stories.
- **Critical Anthologies and Essays**: Beyond traditional fiction, Hartwell edited books of literary criticism, such as Samuel R. Delany's early collections, helping broaden academic engagement with speculative fiction.
- **Contributions to Magazines and Imprints**: He was involved in editing major science fiction magazines and helped found important imprints like Timescape, which published award-winning speculative fiction.

## Hartwell’s Impact on Speculative Fiction

Hartwell’s editorial vision had broad influence throughout the science fiction and fantasy community. He was known for:

- Identifying promising authors and giving them a platform through anthologies and original publishing lines.
- Championing diversity in the genre, giving space to international voices and new trends.
- Supporting literary criticism and analysis, enhancing scholarly understanding of speculative fiction.
- Serving as editor and publisher of respected periodicals, including "The Little Magazine."
- Holding leadership roles in organizations such as the World Fantasy Convention and administering awards like the Philip K. Dick Award.

## Recognition and Legacy

David G. Hartwell received numerous accolades throughout his life, reflecting the high regard in which he was held:

- World Fantasy Life Achievement Award posthumously in 2016.
- Multiple Hugo Award nominations and wins in various categories, especially for professional editing.
- Consistent recognition from readers and peers in the "Locus" annual poll.

His editorial selections, especially those appearing in anthologies like "The Dark Descent," have shaped how generations of readers engage with speculative fiction, offering a lens into contemporary and innovative trends within the genre.

## Conclusion

In summary, while David G. Hartwell edited countless works and anthologies throughout his distinguished career, "**The Dark Descent**" remains a signature piece of literature that demonstrates his editorial acumen and deep commitment to advancing speculative fiction. As a World Fantasy Award-winning anthology, it continues to be remembered and celebrated as part of Hartwell’s enduring literary legacy.

Among Upstate New York’s tallest buildings, the one located in Buffalo is the **Seneca One Tower**. This tower holds the distinction of being the tallest building in Buffalo and ranks as the second-tallest in the entire Upstate New York region. To understand its significance and context among Upstate’s skyline, let’s explore what makes Seneca One Tower notable and how it compares to other prominent skyscrapers in the area.

---

## Overview of Seneca One Tower

**Seneca One Tower**, originally known as Marine Midland Center and later One HSBC Center, is a 40-story skyscraper situated in downtown Buffalo, New York. Completed between 1969 and 1974, this modern architectural landmark stands out both for its height and historical role in the city’s development. At 529 feet (161 meters), Seneca One Tower is not only the tallest building in Buffalo but also an important symbol of the city’s economic growth and architectural ambition.

### Key Facts about Seneca One Tower

| Feature                  | Description                                 |
|--------------------------|---------------------------------------------|
| Location                 | Downtown Buffalo, New York                  |
| Height                   | 529 feet (161 meters)                       |
| Number of Stories        | 40                                          |
| Year Completed           | 1974                                        |
| Original Name            | Marine Midland Center                       |
| Previous Names           | One HSBC Center                             |

---

## Historical and Architectural Significance

Buffalo has a rich history of architectural innovation, especially in the field of skyscraper construction. In the late 19th and early 20th centuries, buildings like the Ellicott Square Building and the Prudential (Guaranty) Building were recognized as some of the earliest true skyscrapers in the United States. However, by the mid-20th century, as corporate America expanded and banks sought large headquarters, projects such as Seneca One Tower became central to Buffalo’s identity.

Seneca One Tower was conceived during a period of urban renewal and was designed to serve as the main headquarters for Marine Midland Bank (later part of HSBC). Its sleek International style contrasts with the ornate Art Deco buildings that dominate parts of Buffalo’s historic core, making it a key feature in the evolution of the city’s modern skyline.

---

## Comparison with Other Upstate New York Tall Buildings

To place Seneca One Tower’s stature in context, consider the ranking of the tallest buildings in Upstate New York outside New York City. The following table provides a clear comparison:

| Rank | Building Name         | City      | Height (ft/meters) | Number of Stories | Notes                                        |
|------|----------------------|-----------|--------------------|-------------------|----------------------------------------------|
| 1    | Erastus Corning Tower| Albany    | 589 / 180          | 44                | Tallest in Upstate NY                        |
| 2    | Seneca One Tower     | Buffalo   | 529 / 161          | 40                | Tallest in Buffalo                           |
| 3    | Empire State Plaza   | Albany    | 514 / 157          | 38                | Second tallest in Albany                     |

As shown above, Seneca One Tower occupies a prestigious position in New York State outside Manhattan. Only Albany’s Erastus Corning Tower surpasses it in height within the region.

---

## Buffalo’s Other Notable High-Rise Buildings

While Seneca One Tower is the undisputed leader in height, Buffalo is also home to several other distinguished skyscrapers and towers that contribute to its urban landscape:

- **Buffalo City Hall**: A 32-story Art Deco structure completed in 1931, often noted for its grandeur and status as one of the largest municipal buildings in the U.S. It stands as another iconic feature of the Buffalo skyline, though its height is surpassed by Seneca One Tower.
- **Ellicott Square Building**: Once hailed as the “world’s largest office building,” this massive Romanesque Revival edifice remains a testament to Buffalo’s historical prominence in architecture and commerce.
- **The Guaranty Building**: Regarded as one of Frank Lloyd Wright’s influences, this landmark showcases Beaux-Arts design.

Despite these impressive competitors, none exceed Seneca One Tower’s height.

---

## Current Role and Renovations

In recent years, Seneca One Tower has undergone significant renovations aimed at revitalizing its appearance and functionality. The building is now undergoing mixed-use redevelopment plans, incorporating retail, hotel, residential, and office spaces. These initiatives reflect ongoing efforts to maintain Buffalo’s prominence as a commercial and cultural hub in Upstate New York.

---

## Summary

Among all the tall buildings constructed in Upstate New York outside New York City, **Seneca One Tower in Buffalo stands out as the city’s tallest and the second-tallest in the region**, narrowly behind Albany’s Erastus Corning Tower. With its impressive height of 529 feet and its architectural significance, Seneca One Tower plays a crucial role in defining Buffalo’s modern skyline. Its story is intertwined with Buffalo’s broader narrative of progress, resilience, and innovation—qualities that continue to shape the city’s future.

A science fiction magazine is a publication dedicated primarily to speculative fiction, typically featuring stories set in imagined worlds or future scenarios involving advanced technology, extraterrestrial life, space exploration, time travel, and other elements that challenge current scientific knowledge or societal norms. These magazines often specialize in short stories, novellas, and serialized novels, and they serve as important platforms for both established and emerging authors in the field of science fiction.

Historically, science fiction magazines have played a critical role in shaping the genre and fostering new voices within it. Many of these publications are periodicals—released on a regular schedule—and may also feature editorial articles, book reviews, and discussions about science fiction literature. Over the decades, numerous magazines have contributed to the growth and diversity of science fiction, especially through their willingness to experiment with new ideas and narrative forms.

## Notable Examples of Science Fiction Magazines

Some of the most influential and long-running science fiction magazines include:

| Magazine Name                             | Country of Origin        | Focus                                    | Notable Facts                                              |
|-------------------------------------------|-------------------------|------------------------------------------|------------------------------------------------------------|
| Amazing Stories                           | United States           | Science Fiction                          | First major science fiction magazine (started in 1926)     |
| Astounding Science Fiction / Analog       | United States           | Science Fiction                          | Renamed to "Analog Science Fiction and Fact"                |
| Galaxy Science Fiction                    | United States           | Science Fiction                          | Known for social and speculative themes                     |
| The Magazine of Fantasy & Science Fiction | United States           | Science Fiction & Fantasy                | Covers both science fiction and fantasy                     |
| Isaac Asimov's Science Fiction Magazine   | United States           | Science Fiction                          | Named after famed author Isaac Asimov                       |
| New Worlds                               | United Kingdom          | Science Fiction                          | Influential British magazine                                |
| Interzone                                 | United Kingdom          | Science Fiction                          | Modern British science fiction publication                   |
| Polluto                                  | United Kingdom          | Science Fiction                          | A newer UK-based magazine                                   |
| Clarkesworld                              | International           | Science Fiction (Online)                 | Leading online-only magazine                                |
| Lightspeed                                | United States           | Science Fiction/Fantasy                  | Online and print magazine                                   |
| Uncanny                                   | United States           | Science Fiction, Fantasy, Poetry         | Recently acclaimed for original stories and art             |

### Historical Perspective

"Amazing Stories," launched in 1926 by Hugo Gernsback, is often credited as the very first magazine devoted exclusively to science fiction. Its founding marked a turning point in publishing, enabling the emergence of science fiction as a distinct literary genre.

"Astounding Science Fiction," which later became "Analog Science Fiction and Fact," has been highly influential since its inception in 1930. It’s known for its rigorous standards and for publishing stories by many renowned authors such as Isaac Asimov, Robert A. Heinlein, and Arthur C. Clarke.

In the UK, "New Worlds," launched in the 1930s, helped establish the country's reputation for science fiction publishing. In more recent years, "Interzone" has become synonymous with modern British science fiction, regularly showcasing cutting-edge works from both British and international writers.

### Digital Age and New Trends

With the rise of the Internet, many science fiction magazines have transitioned to digital formats, broadening their reach and reducing production costs. Online magazines like "Clarkesworld" have gained significant international recognition for their high-quality content and innovative approaches to publishing.

Many contemporary magazines blend science fiction with fantasy, horror, or related speculative genres, although there are still specialized publications focusing exclusively on science fiction.

### Role in the Community

Science fiction magazines offer a vital platform for both readers and writers:

- They provide exposure for new talent and enable experimentation with innovative storytelling techniques.
- They foster a sense of community among science fiction enthusiasts.
- Many notable science fiction writers have had their first stories published in genre-specific magazines, sometimes leading to broader success.

### What Defines a Science Fiction Magazine?

The primary criterion for a science fiction magazine is its focus on speculative fiction written with a strong basis in imaginative science and technology. While some magazines may mix in fantasy and horror stories, those dedicated to science fiction are distinguished by the prevalence of stories grounded in plausible (or highly speculative) scientific concepts.

Additionally, many science fiction magazines have shaped their unique identities over time, either by curating works that challenge social conventions or by promoting narratives that explore the implications of technological progress.

## Conclusion

Science fiction magazines are diverse in content, format, and history. Classics like "Amazing Stories" and "Astounding Science Fiction" have laid the foundation for the modern genre, while newer publications continue to expand and redefine what science fiction can be. Whether in print or digital form, these magazines remain central to the evolution and enjoyment of speculative fiction worldwide.

Mani Ratnam is one of India’s most acclaimed filmmakers, renowned for his contributions to cinema both as a director, screenwriter, and producer. His multifaceted involvement in films often goes beyond directing, frequently including significant roles in scriptwriting and production. Among his numerous works, the movie "Dil Se.." (1998) stands out as an example where Mani Ratnam played both critical roles—he wrote the screenplay and also produced the film.

## Background on "Dil Se.."

"Dil Se.." is a 1998 Indian romantic drama film directed by Mani Ratnam and starring Shah Rukh Khan, Manisha Koirala, and Preity Zinta. The film is set against the backdrop of political unrest in Assam and features a love story with elements of terrorism, suspense, and emotional depth. It is notable as the third installment in Mani Ratnam’s “Terrorism Trilogy,” following "Roja" (1992) and "Bombay" (1995).

## Mani Ratnam's Dual Role: Screenplay and Production

In "Dil Se..", Mani Ratnam not only directed but also co-wrote the screenplay, collaborating with Tigmanshu Dhulia. This collaboration ensured the film retained his signature storytelling style, incorporating themes of love, conflict, and national identity, which are hallmarks of his cinematic vision.

Equally significant is Mani Ratnam's role as a producer. The film was jointly produced by Mani Ratnam himself, Ram Gopal Varma, and Shekhar Kapur. His involvement in production meant he had creative control over various aspects of the film’s development, from financing and scheduling to overseeing post-production processes. By producing the film himself, Mani Ratnam facilitated the realization of his unique artistic goals without external interference, ensuring the vision for "Dil Se.." remained consistent throughout.

### Key Contributions:

- **Screenplay:** Mani Ratnam crafted the core narrative and dialogues, working closely with other writers. His focus on complex characters and layered storytelling shaped the film’s narrative structure and emotional resonance.
- **Production:** As a producer, Mani Ratnam managed logistical and financial aspects, secured distribution channels, and handled marketing strategies. His dual role allowed him to make key decisions regarding casting, location, and technical resources, maximizing the creative potential of "Dil Se..".

## Other Films Where Mani Ratnam Served as Writer and Producer

While "Dil Se.." is the most prominent example discussed in mainstream sources, it’s important to acknowledge that Mani Ratnam has taken similar roles in several other films. For instance, "Kadal" (2013) is noted as a film that Mani Ratnam co-wrote and co-produced under his banner, Madras Talkies. However, information specific to "Dil Se.." is more robustly documented in widely accessible references, making it the preferred answer based on available evidence.

## Impact of Mani Ratnam’s Dual Involvement

Having Mani Ratnam actively contribute to both scriptwriting and production leads to a distinctive cinematic outcome:
- **Creative Consistency:** The alignment between story and execution ensures films reflect the filmmaker’s intended message and artistic standards.
- **Innovative Storytelling:** His hands-on involvement in both domains enables fresh narratives and risk-taking, especially in genres blending romance and social issues.
- **Global Recognition:** "Dil Se.." gained international acclaim for its bold subject matter and stylistic choices, partly due to Mani Ratnam’s holistic leadership.

## Conclusion

In summary, "Dil Se.." is the movie for which Mani Ratnam worked on the script and served as producer. His direct engagement in both screenplay and production is a defining feature of this work, setting it apart among his broader filmography. Through "Dil Se..", Mani Ratnam demonstrated how intertwined roles of writing and producing can yield powerful and memorable films that resonate both domestically and internationally.

An example of the marine vessel classification German Type U 31 is the submarine SM U-31. The German Type U 31 refers to a class of ocean-going submarines built for the Imperial German Navy during World War I. These vessels were designed to operate at sea for extended periods and played a significant role in naval warfare during the conflict. The Type U 31 class was constructed between 1912 and 1915, comprising a total of eleven submarines. Each individual boat in this group—such as SM U-31, SM U-32, SM U-33, and up through SM U-41—is considered an example of this classification.

## Overview of German Type U 31 Submarine Class

The German Type U 31 represented a substantial advancement in submarine technology for its era. This class was based on previous developments but incorporated several improvements for increased operational range, durability, and combat effectiveness. The construction and deployment of these submarines marked a transition toward modern submarine fleets capable of conducting offensive operations far from home ports.

### Key Characteristics

German Type U 31 submarines shared many design features that made them effective both as attack platforms and for reconnaissance missions:

- **Displacement**: Surface: Approximately 743 tons; Submerged: Around 865 tons
- **Length**: Overall length was about 64.7 meters, with the pressure hull being slightly shorter
- **Beam**: Overall width (beam) around 5.9 meters, with the pressure hull narrower at 4.0 meters
- **Draught**: Roughly 3.9 meters
- **Propulsion**: Two Germania six-cylinder, two-stroke diesel engines for surface operations, and two Siemens-Schuckert double-acting electric motors for underwater propulsion
- **Speed**: Top surface speed of about 14 knots, while submerged the top speed dropped to approximately 8.3 knots
- **Range**: Cruising range up to 9,040 nautical miles at 5 knots on the surface
- **Armament**: Typically equipped with four torpedo tubes—two in the bow and two in the stern—and carried a complement of six torpedoes. Additionally, they were often armed with a deck gun, initially SK L/30, later upgraded to SK L/45 guns on some boats. The crew complement numbered four officers and about 31 enlisted men.

| Specification           | Value                |
|-------------------------|---------------------|
| Displacement (surface)  | ~743 tons           |
| Displacement (submerged)| ~865 tons           |
| Length                  | ~64.7 meters        |
| Beam                    | ~5.9 meters         |
| Draught                 | ~3.9 meters         |
| Crew                    | 4 officers + 31     |

## Examples of Individual Vessels

Each vessel within the German Type U 31 class is an example of the classification. Notably, several of these submarines achieved fame during World War I, with commanders like Lothar von Arnauld de la Perière, Max Valentiner, and Walter Forstmann leading successful campaigns. Some well-known examples include:

- **SM U-31**: The lead vessel of the class, commissioned in 1913 and lost in action in the North Sea in early 1915 after striking a mine.
- **SM U-32**
- **SM U-33**
- **SM U-34**
- **SM U-35**: Commanded by Lothar von Arnauld de la Perière, who was one of the most successful U-boat commanders, sinking over 400 ships.
- **SM U-36**
- **SM U-37**
- **SM U-38**: Commanded by Max Valentiner, another top-scoring commander.
- **SM U-39**
- **SM U-40**
- **SM U-41**

These submarines were widely deployed in various theaters of war, including the North Sea, English Channel, Mediterranean, and Black Sea. Their ability to operate independently and surprise enemy shipping routes made them formidable adversaries.

## Operational History and Impact

The German Type U 31 submarines formed the backbone of Germany’s U-boat fleet early in World War I. They conducted long-range patrols, attacked Allied merchant convoys, and supported fleet operations. Their introduction and use set precedents for subsequent submarine classes in both technical design and tactical doctrine.

Some submarines, particularly those commanded by renowned leaders, became legendary for their effectiveness and success. The class contributed significantly to the so-called “First Battle of the Atlantic,” where unrestricted submarine warfare was first systematically employed against Allied supply lines.

However, many of the boats did not survive the war. Losses were attributed to mines, depth charges, patrol aircraft, and ship collisions. Despite this, the Type U 31 submarines left an enduring mark on naval warfare and influenced future designs of military submarines globally.

## Significance of the Classification

The classification German Type U 31 serves as a standard reference for historians, naval architects, and military enthusiasts when discussing early 20th-century submarine development. It denotes a particular design philosophy and technological achievement that bridged the gap between experimental submarines and the highly sophisticated models of later decades.

Vessels bearing this classification are studied both for their engineering feats and their contribution to maritime history. The name "Type U 31" thus represents not just a series of individual submarines, but a milestone in the evolution of underwater warfare.

---

In summary, an example of the marine vessel classification German Type U 31 is any of the submarines built under this design scheme—for instance, SM U-31, SM U-32, SM U-33, and up to SM U-41. Collectively, these boats exemplify the characteristics, performance metrics, and historical roles of the German Type U 31 class within the broader context of naval history.

The Seattle Storm, a professional women's basketball team in the Women's National Basketball Association (WNBA), is based in Seattle, Washington, USA. Their draft selections have been historically drawn largely from players who have played in U.S. collegiate programs. However, the franchise has had notable international representation in its drafts, especially during expansion years and key strategic picks.

### First Draft Selection: The Czech Connection

When the Seattle Storm was established in 2000 as an expansion franchise, the team was allowed to select veteran players from other WNBA teams in the Expansion Draft. The very first draft choice for the Storm was Kamila Vodičková, a center originally from what was then Czechoslovakia (now known as the Czech Republic). Her selection marked a significant international milestone for the franchise.

Kamila Vodičková brought a distinct skill set and experience from European basketball circuits and represented the first instance of the Storm drafting a player directly from outside North America. She became an important figure in the early years of the team’s history, contributing offensively and providing leadership at the center position.

Her presence on the roster highlighted the WNBA’s growing reputation as an internationally recognized league and signaled the Storm’s willingness to look globally for talent, even while most selections typically came from within the United States.

### Other Notable International Draft Picks

While the majority of the Seattle Storm’s draft history features American players from NCAA programs, there have been moments when the franchise selected or signed players from other countries:

- **Lauren Jackson**: In 2001, following her time playing professionally in Europe, Jackson was chosen by the Utah Starzz in the WNBA draft. Though technically not a direct Seattle draft pick, she quickly joined the Storm through a trade, becoming one of the most iconic figures in league history. Jackson, from Australia, was among the first high-profile international stars in the WNBA and played a crucial role in Seattle’s rise to championship status.

- **Abby Bishop**: The Storm have also signed international players such as Australian forward Abby Bishop. While these signings were not made via the official WNBA draft, they added international depth to the roster and showcased the team’s engagement with global talent pipelines.

### Statistics: Drafts by Country

Below is a summary of the main countries from which the Seattle Storm have drawn draft selections and key international players:

| Country          | Notable Player(s)      | Role/Period           |
|------------------|-----------------------|-----------------------|
| United States    | Many (e.g., Jewell Loyd, Sue Bird, Kaleena Mosqueda-Lewis) | Most draft picks over the years |
| Czech Republic   | Kamila Vodičková       | Expansion Draft 2000, Center |
| Australia        | Lauren Jackson*        | Trading/Signing, Star Power |
| Other            | (various, e.g., Canada - only non-drafted signings) | Minor or indirect involvement |

*\*Lauren Jackson was not originally drafted by the Storm, but was traded in shortly after her initial selection.*

### Patterns in Drafting International Talent

- **Expansion Era**: The Storm’s first expansion draft allowed them to acquire experienced players from other franchises, leading to Kamila Vodičková from the Czech Republic as their inaugural draft selection.
- **Post-Expansion and Dynasty Years**: After expanding their roster through U.S. college drafts, the Storm often filled key roles with established international stars like Lauren Jackson via trades rather than the traditional entry draft.
- **Recent Years**: While the Storm continue to focus on domestic college talent, they remain open to international competition for both draft eligibility and signing free agents.

### Summary

In conclusion, the Seattle Storm’s draft selections have primarily come from the United States due to the structure of the WNBA draft and the predominant pipeline of talent from American colleges. However, the franchise’s first-ever draft pick was Kamila Vodičková, who originated from the Czech Republic (then Czechoslovakia). This remains a unique fact in WNBA and Storm history.

Additionally, while most international players entered via trading or free agency, the example of Kamila Vodičková illustrates the Storm’s openness to seeking elite talent from around the world. Therefore, the answer to the question “From which country did Seattle Storm make draft selections?” is:

**The Czech Republic**, as it was the origin of their first draft selection. Over time, they have also engaged with players from Australia and other countries, but the Czech Republic stands out as the source for their inaugural franchise draft choice.

Combined together, highly acidic water, low temperature, and a lack of oxygen preserve but severely tan their skin.

Gallagh Man was found buried in a deep grave in a peat bog, dressed in a long leather mantle, and pinned down by two long wooden stakes.

2. <docid: 26563275__1> [Gallagh Man His teeth and hair were almost fully p...]
Gallagh Man His teeth and hair were almost fully preserved, and even though the body is severely dehydrated and thus shriveled, it has suffered from little shrinkage and it is described overall as exceptionally well-preserved. The body was bought by the Royal Irish Academy in 1829 and is now held by the archaeology department of the National Museum of Ireland, Dublin, where it is one of four such bodies in their collection. Discovery. Gallagh Man was discovered in 1821 by labourers working for the O'Kelly family while digging peat from a bog in Gallagh, a townland outside Castleblakeney, County Galway. The O'Kellys were a well-known and powerful family in the region, whose ancestors had built a castle at Gallagh in the medieval period.

3. <docid: 26563275__3> [Gallagh Man The withy hoop found around his neck m...]
Gallagh Man The withy hoop found around his neck may originally have been the part of a spancel used for restraining animals. It was probably used as a garrotte to strangle him, probably during a ritual involving human sacrifice, given that most of such bodies from this period are young males aged 25 to 40 years old, and like many of these victims, his hair had been closely cropped. It is also possible that he was murdered outside of a ritual context, or was a criminal who was put to death. However, the willow rope strongly suggests ritual sacrifice; they often appear for this purpose in early Irish mythological stories such as that of the "Táin Bó Cúailnge". Condition.

4. <docid: 26563275__4> [Gallagh Man Radiocarbon analysis suggests the man ...]
Gallagh Man Radiocarbon analysis suggests the man was around 25 years old when he died. His teeth, long dark-reddish hair and beard were well preserved. Unlike many bodies of this time, it does not appear to have shrunk in size, and retains most of its original proportion. Elements of his burial indicate he did not die from natural causes. The body was pinned down by stakes, and a withy hoop was found wrapped around his throat. He was buried naked except for a long deerskin mantle or cape, which reached to his knees, while a long stick was placed in the grave alongside him. The leather mantle was badly damaged during disinterment, but surviving fragments are on display at the National Museum.

5. <docid: 26563275__5> [Gallagh Man It was sewn together with three knotte...]
Gallagh Man It was sewn together with three knotted gut threads. A 19th-century study states that the "regularity and closeness of the stitches are most remarkable, as shown by the accompanying cut [of a proportion of one of the joinings... see image to right]... this closure was effected by... a looped stitch similar to that used in working a button-hole, so that by having each stitch knotted the chances of ripping was lessened." The body was fastened to the end of the deep grave by two pointed wooden stakes which appear to have been placed so that either the body would not rise to the surface, or that the victim's soul would not escape.

Bog bodies, or bog people, are the naturally preserved corpses of humans and some animals recovered from peat bog s. The bodies have been most commonly found in the Northern European countries of Denmark, Germany, The Netherlands, the United Kingdom and Ireland. Reports of bog bodies surfaced during the early 1700s. In 1965, the German scientist Alfred Dieck catalogued more than 1,850 bog bodies, but later scholarship revealed much of Dieck's work was erroneous. Hundreds of bog bodies have been recovered and studied, although it is believed that only around 45 bog bodies remain intact today.

Bog body A bog body is a human cadaver that has been naturally mummified in a peat bog. Such bodies, sometimes known as bog people, are both geographically and chronologically widespread, having been dated to between and the Second World War. The unifying factor of the bog bodies is that they have been found in peat and are partially preserved; however, the actual levels of preservation vary widely from perfectly preserved to mere skeletons. Unlike most ancient human remains, bog bodies often retain their skin and internal organs due to the unusual conditions of the surrounding area. Combined together, highly acidic water, low temperature, and a lack of oxygen preserve but severely tan their skin.
